results.title: How insects help us
results.brief_description: A junior social studies film. Develops four ideas about insects: that all are worth observing and learning about; some are helpful; others harmful; and some are beautiful. Behaviour of wasps, ants, bees, flies, grasshoppers and others is studied.
results.description: A junior social studies film. Develops four ideas about insects: that all are worth observing and learning about; some are helpful; others harmful; and some are beautiful. Behaviour of wasps, ants, bees, flies, grasshoppers and others is studied.

results.title: How good is a 'good guy'?
results.creator_credit: Jack Denove, Leon S. Gold and Roundtable Productions
results.brief_description: Indicates the many hidden problems caused when supervisors are more concerned with their own needs than with the needs of their men and their company.

results.title: How fibres are spun
results.brief_description: Shows methods of spinning that were practised before the Industrial Revolution, and so elucidates the basic operations of the mechanical spindle. Shows the opening out and carding of wool and cotton by hand.
results.description: Shows methods of spinning that were practised before the Industrial Revolution, and so elucidates the basic operations of the mechanical spindle. Shows the opening out and carding of wool and cotton by hand.

results.title: How effective is your reading?
results.brief_description: This film is designed to help students and adults improve their reading skills. Demonstrates methods of faster reading and better understanding, emphasising at the same time the need for practice. Illustrates a number of specific reading skills, including how to read in larger thought groups, to skim, to read when in search of information, and how to read rapidly but at the same time comprehend fully.

results.title: How does a rainbow feel?
results.creator_credit: Donald Wise, Stanley S Madeja and WH Productions
results.brief_description: Shows the variety of aesthetic educational qualities in the environment - sounds, shapes, patterns, colours and textures. Children are seen exploring and discovering such areas as body movement, shapes, points of view, characterisation and dramatic plot. In the final minutes of the film, a class of primary school children create a dramatic plot about a young boy with a violin named the “Rainbow King”. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: How does a candle burn?
results.brief_description: Demonstrates how the properties of candle wax change as the wax is transformed from a solid to a gaseous state and explores the nature and shape of the flame and the function of the wick.

results.title: How do you read? (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Harris Watts, Stephen Rose and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Being unable to read is a personal disaster. Learning to read at an early age is very important. This film demonstrates various modern techniques and devices used to increase reading speed, and it shows that the speed of reading and the rate of comprehension are related to the material being studied.

results.title: How do children think?
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Discovery and Experience”.
Discusses Piaget’s research and theories of the main periods of development in children. To advance beyond the stage of primitive concrete operations, children need opportunities for the kind of work they do in primary schools, based on activity, discussion, and the growth of social relationships.

results.title: How death came to earth
results.creator_credit: Ishu Patel and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A legend from India, interpreted on film by a film-maker from India. It is a story of gods and men, of suns and moons and earth, interpreted with an animation style and a richness of colour and design as arresting to the eye as the story and the music are to the ear. Sometimes the illustrations are painted on cells, sometimes the figures are cut-outs moving across shining grounds, but always the pace is gentle, inevitable.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ishu Patel and National Film Board of Canada
